answers.author: Robert Woods
answers.text:
Our Public Works department uses a fee-for-service model for costing activities. That is, it's generally based on fully burdened costs per hour X billable hours to the activity. We use our Project Accounting system to track hours and bill back charges.
The general approach is like this:
Total FTE Hours (usually 2080)
Less leave time (sick, vacation, etc)
Less at work, but non-billable (meetings, training, unaccounted)
= Estimated billable hours
charge rate =  ( budgeted: Salaries & Benefits + materials/Supplies/Other expenses + central services + other internal "overhead) / billable hours. 
Obviously, this is the generalized approach, but if an engineer works 4 hours on a project at a rate of $125/hr, the project is billed $500. Doesn't matter what it is for. The same approach could be appled to any governmental unit. The requiremenst is that the methodology be consistently applied across the work unit.
Overall the operations revenue covers their costs. We use an internal services fund to run the operation as an enterprise.

author: Michael McGowan
text: I am doing research on best practices for cost recovery programs for the City of Chicago.  The goal is to compare best practices in other municipalities to current practice and to consider new programs such as driving under the influence and emergency response for automobile accidents.  What cost programs does your municipality use?  Which are effective?  Can you direct me to any materials on the subject?
title: Cost Recovery Programs Best Practice
